image.altText: An ASX board shot by John Gunn in Deccember 2022.

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Bank data shows consumers spent more on health and fitness last month, but it expects further interest rate rises to dampen demand. The ASX is weaker despite 13-month high on Wall Street.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has come off its lows over lunchtime. The ASX 200 index is flat, after weaker commodity prices pulled the benchmark index lower in the morning. Miners and energy stocks are still weighing on the market, while technology is leading the gains after big tech drove Wall Street overnight. Domino's Pizza (-7.9 per cent) is the worst performer in the ASX 200, while uranium firm Paladin Energy (+11.5 per cent) is the best performer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shares steady at midday

children.content: The Australian share market has come off its lows over lunchtime.
The ASX 200 index is flat, after weaker commodity prices pulled the benchmark index lower in the morning.
Miners and energy stocks are still weighing on the market, while technology is leading the gains after big tech drove Wall Street overnight.
Domino's Pizza (-7.9 per cent) is the worst performer in the ASX 200, while uranium firm Paladin Energy (+11.5 per cent) is the best performer.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Home prices rose over the first few months of the year according to the Bureau of Statistics despite higher interest rates. The total value of Australia's homes increased by $140 billion to $9.9 trillion over the March quarter. That's a lot of money, although the value of residential dwellings did reach $10.2 trillion for the first time in March last year. The mean price of Australian homes lifted by $8,500 to $896,000 with the total number of dwellings up 52,000 to just over 11 million over the first three months of 2023. New South Wales has the highest home prices in the country with a mean price of $1.15 million. The value of Australian homes rose in all states except Tasmania, the Northern Territory, and the ACT. The data from the ABS is a bit delayed, with the latest data from property analysts CoreLogic showing that home values increased for the third month in a row in May. Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian homes worth $9.9 trillion

featuredLink.title: Rosemary paid $35k for a modest Sydney home. When it went to auction 45 years later, she thought she 'was going to faint'

children.content: Home prices rose over the first few months of the year according to the Bureau of Statistics despite higher interest rates.
The total value of Australia's homes increased by $140 billion to $9.9 trillion over the March quarter.

props.alt: Graph showing value of Australian homes

children.content: Home values
(ABS)
That's a lot of money, although the value of residential dwellings did reach $10.2 trillion for the first time in March last year.
The mean price of Australian homes lifted by $8,500 to $896,000 with the total number of dwellings up 52,000 to just over 11 million over the first three months of 2023.
New South Wales has the highest home prices in the country with a mean price of $1.15 million.
The value of Australian homes rose in all states except Tasmania, the Northern Territory, and the ACT.
The data from the ABS is a bit delayed, with the latest data from property analysts CoreLogic showing that home values increased for the third month in a row in May.
Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While consumer confidence is near recession lows, business confidence is also taking a hit with "worrying" signs of a slowing in activity. National Australia Bank says in its latest monthly survey that business conditions continue to ease last month with notable declines in trading, profits and employment. NAB says confidence fell to -4 index points over May, well below the levels seen early in 2023, and business conditions fell 7 points to 8 index points. Forward orders fell sharply, especially in retail and wholesale as consumers cut back on spending. But NAB chief economist Alan Oster says while conditions are weakening, they are still remain above average levels. “Business conditions recorded a solid decline in May, and it appears the gradual easing we have seen through early 2023 appears to be strengthening,” said NAB Chief Economist Alan Oster. He says the decline in confidence occurred across most industries, although mining, manufacturing, transport and utilities saw "modest improvements." “Confidence fell back into negative territory though has bounced around within the 0 to -4 index point range in recent month,” he said. “Our bigger worry is the sharp decline in forward orders in the month.” "The forward orders measure typically leads business conditions and historically has been the best measure of economic activity”. “If orders persist at these levels we could well see ongoing sharp falls in business conditions, highlighting the risks around economic growth through the middle of this year.” “With the easing in business conditions accelerating and forward orders falling sharply, there is a growing risk that the RBA’s attempts to maintain an even keel ‘run aground."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business confidence falls

children.content: While consumer confidence is near recession lows, business confidence is also taking a hit with "worrying" signs of a slowing in activity.
National Australia Bank says in its latest monthly survey that business conditions continue to ease last month with notable declines in trading, profits and employment.
NAB says confidence fell to -4 index points over May, well below the levels seen early in 2023, and business conditions fell 7 points to 8 index points.

props.alt: Graph showing business confidence and conditions

children.content: Business confidence
(NAB)
Forward orders fell sharply, especially in retail and wholesale as consumers cut back on spending.
But NAB chief economist Alan Oster says while conditions are weakening, they are still remain above average levels.
“Business conditions recorded a solid decline in May, and it appears the gradual easing we have seen through early 2023 appears to be strengthening,” said NAB Chief Economist Alan Oster.
He says the decline in confidence occurred across most industries, although mining, manufacturing, transport and utilities saw "modest improvements."
“Confidence fell back into negative territory though has bounced around within the 0 to -4 index point range in recent month,” he said.
“Our bigger worry is the sharp decline in forward orders in the month.”
"The forward orders measure typically leads business conditions and historically has been the best measure of economic activity”.
“If orders persist at these levels we could well see ongoing sharp falls in business conditions, highlighting the risks around economic growth through the middle of this year.”
“With the easing in business conditions accelerating and forward orders falling sharply, there is a growing risk that the RBA’s attempts to maintain an even keel ‘run aground."
